title: Power - resistors 1 and 2 have different V and I

content.question: Two resistors, Resistor <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Resistor <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, are connected to different power sources. Resistor <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has a potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and a current <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and Resistor <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has a potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub 2 equals 3 delta V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> and a current <math alttext="I sub 2 equals one fifth I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="P sub 2, to P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> of the power dissipated in Resistor <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> to the power dissipated in Resistor <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> ?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
